title: What's the most original ending for a murder novel that you came across? - Quora

response.answer_text: Donald E. Westlake wrote the best and most humorous detective novels anywhere. He has one book where the main character murders an adversary and makes it look the he was the intended victim. The police believe him completely as they investigate, sympathetic to his predicament that someone is trying to kill him. The lead detective is thorough, dedicated and honest and takes the murderer under his wing. He even brings him home for dinner and introduces him to his wife. The killer seduces the detective’s wife and they carry on an affair. It looks like he’s going to get away with everything but then the killer is arrested when they find an incriminating piece of evidence - but it was fabricated. The detective discovered the affair and planted it. He doesn’t care that the “real killer” will go free - just that the guy banging his wife is put away. The killer is captured totally by his own pride and vanity. I can’t remember the name of the book but Westlake wrote dozens, including some made into movies. He was a giant. He died some time ago.

I agree with Sukh Dutta’s selections, but if you haven’t read the books DO NOT READ ANYTHING MORE THAN THE TITLES. Read the books themselves. For other candidates: Anything by John Dickson Carr is generally worth reading — several time — and the ending of The Burning Court is surprising and controversial; I think it’s quite original. The very last line of the short story “The House in Goblin Wood” qualifies. The ending of his “The Wrong Problem” is brilliant. The structure and solution of She Died a Lady is highly creative, to my mind. I have certain biases for certain kinds of endings, and while I can’t say it’s the most original ending, I find the conclusion of the Perry Mason mystery The Case of the Perjured Parrot to be highly satisfying. Another great ending to a mystery with more than one original component is Rex Stout’s Nero Wolfe mystery, The Doorbell Rang. A very astonishing Ellery Queen mystery novel, with a unique ending, is And On the Eighth Day. For a foray into the overlap of science fiction and mystery, I think the ending of Asimov’s The Naked Sun is remarkable. To appreciate it, one must first read The Caves of Steel. But any excuse to read Asimov should be eagerly accepted. And back to Agatha Christie: the short story “Witness for the Prosecution” has, to my mind, the best last line.
